column4: well, one easy way to do it would be to use the openssl package.
openssl bf -salt -in inputfile.txt -out outputfile.txt
It will prompt you for a passphrase;  you can also specify the passphrase with a command-line option, but then of course the passphrase is in your shell history :-)
what you are suggesting sounds interesting. so this would allow me to password protect any type of file, and not just openoffice ones?
I am using ubuntu on my laptop
so does that mean I can use it to password protect any file?
Yes.
Any file, just as the example I just gave.
It's actually possible to do tricksier things, I've read, but I haven't tried.
Also note that this doesn't necessarily protect you against disk recovery, etc, so it's not super-secure.

Well you could even encrypt them on the server, before downloading htem.
can you explain what the bf -salt -in bit does in your suggestion?
bf is the code for the type of encryption yo're going to use, blowfish, which from what I've read is the recommended one to go wtih if you don't know what you're doing.
Blowfish was invented by Bruce Schneier, the god of computer security, and is generally regarded as pretty sedure.
-salt is a flag that really ought to be on by default, again, always use it if you don't know what you're doing.

In a nutshell an encryption salt is part of the inputs to encryption. Using a good salt value makes the encryption stronger (i.e. less predicatble and therefore harder to deduce the key), but also makes it take more resources.
-in inputfilename.txt and "-out outputfilename.txt" are pretty self-explanatory.
